HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 16, 1926.

A REAL COLLEGE MAGAZINE
College, as some astute observer has in all probability anticipated us in expressing it, is a very complex institution; so
complex indeed, that few, even while they are in the very midst
of it, are able to correlate and assign correct valuations to the
varied foims of activity ranging from the most abstruse problems of scientific or literary research to the freshman-sophomore
rush' or the collegiate cab contest which are all corrected by
the word "college."
Nearly all of the periodicals devoted to college and college
life avoid the nearly impossible task of rec-onciling its many
different aspects by treating only one. However, no matter
how excellent these magazines may be, they always have the
weakness of presenting a one-sided view.
The one magazine which presents college in anything like
adequate
an
light is the Intereollegiate World. The fact that
it is a Baltimore publication and has Dr. Ames as one of its
advisory editors should make it of special interest.
The four numbers which have already appeared are sufficient for a pretty correct estimate. We are delighted to find in
the Intercollegiate Woild a magazine which sanely and faithfully portrays the best in nearly every phase of college life.
Besides covering the three main fields of scholarship, athletics,
and non-athletic activity, the editors have included articles by
college men who are now in the business or professional world
which are especially stimulating and interesting.
The Intercollegiate World is truely the college man's magazine, undoubtedly the leader in its field. We sincerely hope •
that in the future it will bepme more widely known on the
campus.

WELCOME, VIRGINIA!
If present preparations are carried out, visiting teams will
receive a most cordial greeting when they arrive in Baltimore to
match their prowess with Johns Hopkins. The newly reorganized Varsity Club is to be congratulated on their admirable
!dans for meeting Virginia tomorrow. The Club has arranged
with the fraternities to have eight machines, each representing
4,ne fraternity, to meet the visiting lacrosse men, at - Union
a tion and conduct them to the field for the game. The Var,i ty Club will likewise take the men in hand at the Civil
;.:ngineering Building tea dance after the game.
•
According to indications, the Virginians will be the recipi,nt s of real Maryland hospitality. This welcoming should help
along the Indian game, which is becoming very popular at
irginia where baseball has long reigned supreme in the Spring.
. lie university that was once a great rival of Hopkins' elevens
;(is fair to become an annual opponent of the Black and Blue
ye. Welcome back again, Virginia!

Yale University has finally
abolished by faculty vote the long
disliked compulsory chapel ruling.

BLUE JAY ORCHESTRA IS
WELL RECEIVED
Makes Favorable Impression Before
New York Dancers At Roseland

Having returned from a successful booking at the Roseland Dance
Hall, Broadway, the Blue Jay Orchestra is besieged with offers of
profitable bookings for the summer, according to Milton Myerberg, manager. Negotiations with
several agents are at present going
on, and the best of many offers
will be accepted.
At New York, the orchestra
played on the platform next to
Fletcher Henderson's orchestra.
This, in itself, was an honor, but
they were honored more by the
great enthusiasm with which the
critical crowds of dancers received
their music. Enoch Light, director of the orchestra, expressed-the
opinion that none of the music
they had ever played in Baltimore
could be at all comparable to the
Isyncopation produced at New
York during Easter week.. In
fact, the Blue Jays were favorably
compared to the best *and most
famous orchestras on Broadway.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 16, 1926.

NEWS-LETTER

MAILBAG
KEYES ANSWERS "TALK"
To the Editor of the et(-8-Letter:
Dear Sir:
There seems to be a good deal
of talk on the Campus regarding
the fact that we are charging only
$1.00 admission for the Army and
Oxford-Cambridge games while it
was announced at the Season
Ticket Sale that we would probably charge $1.50 or $2.00.
The decision to charge only
$1.00 was not made by any one person but was done after due consideratiOn ancl consultation with
th
various persons concerned
with such details. We were ,asked
to charge no more than $1.00 for
the English game by the person
arranging their trip and we did
not think it fair to charge $2.00
for the Army gathe only.
•
I trust that you will publish
this letter and that it will go a
long way in clearing up the minds
of the students in this matter.
We regret that- tickets may have
been sold with the idea of advance
charge on these games, but inasmuch as people holding Season
Tickets are still saving $3.60, I do
not see how. they have any cause
for complaint.
Very truly yours,
NORMAN CHASE KEYES,
Graduate Manager.

A few reasons why The Guardian
Life Insurance Company of America is the ideal Life Insurance
Company for you to represent.
I. Its great financial strength — its
income from investments alone being considerably more than enough
to pay all death claims.
2. Its fairness in dealing with policyholders.
3. Its history of consistent healthy
growth since its birth, in 1860.
4. Its willingness to co-operate with
its representatives in the field.
5. Its careful selection of only the
highest grade representatives.
6. Its personal instruction and supervision of new personnel.
7.'Its automatic guarantee of success
to the man who properly fits himself for the business.
8. Its opportunities extended to its
field force in advancement.

DR. THATCH RECOVERING
To the Editor of the \ cir- N-Letter:
Dear Sir:
I think a great many of your
readers wilL be interested to know
that Dr. Charles Thach, who has
been very seriously ill with sleeping sickness, is now on the way to
recovery. Dr. Thach has been in
the hospital for about eight weeks
but will be able to leave within the
next two weeks probably. He
probably will not be entirely recovered until the end of the summer but he expects to resume his
work at Washington Square College next fall.
Yours truly,
MARGARET K. THACH,
(Mrs. C. C. Thach.)

change fellowships annually, the
Foundation arranges for the exchange of lecturing professors between the two countries. Professor -Jean Massart, a noted Botanist of Brussels, visited Johns Hopkins in the spring of 1924 under
the auspices of the Foundation.
Dr. Briggs will spend several
months in Europe before taking
up his course of study in the
autumn.

It was only a few, months after
need for an improved method of Pierce had completed the gradremote metering, and R. T. uate. student course at WestingPierce, Maine '15,in the employ
house that he was given an assign-

ment in the instrument section
of the engineering department.
He took it merely as a "fill-in"
job. Soon he saw that instruments play a vital part in every
electrical operation. As an instrument engineer, Pierce spent
several weeks on the U. S. S.
Tennessee and the Colorado
during their trial runs. He has
ridden in the cabs of electric
locomotives. He is in closer
touch with radio than anyone
not a radio engineer.
A design engineer comes continuously in contact with sales
negotiations, and Pierce's contact with them proved so beneficial that he was lately made
head of the Instrument Section
of the Sales Department, which
means that he really has charge
of the sale of all instruments to
Westinghouse customers.

Wins Scholarship
Te Ming Ku, of Peking, China,
who received his A. B. degree at
Hopkins in 1921, has just won a
fellowship in Economics at Clark
University regarded as one of the
greatest honors at that institution. He has only been in America since 1922. .He is a Chinese
government student, belonging to
a prominent Peking family. Last
year he was awarded an M. A.
degree at Columbia.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 16, 1926.

A REAL COLLEGE MAGAZINE
College, as some astute observer has in all probability anticipated us in expressing it, is a very complex institution; so
complex indeed, that few, even while they are in the very midst
of it, are able to correlate and assign correct valuations to the
varied foims of activity ranging from the most abstruse problems of scientific or literary research to the freshman-sophomore
rush' or the collegiate cab contest which are all corrected by
the word "college."
Nearly all of the periodicals devoted to college and college
life avoid the nearly impossible task of rec-onciling its many
different aspects by treating only one. However, no matter
how excellent these magazines may be, they always have the
weakness of presenting a one-sided view.
The one magazine which presents college in anything like
adequate
an
light is the Intereollegiate World. The fact that
it is a Baltimore publication and has Dr. Ames as one of its
advisory editors should make it of special interest.
The four numbers which have already appeared are sufficient for a pretty correct estimate. We are delighted to find in
the Intercollegiate Woild a magazine which sanely and faithfully portrays the best in nearly every phase of college life.
Besides covering the three main fields of scholarship, athletics,
and non-athletic activity, the editors have included articles by
college men who are now in the business or professional world
which are especially stimulating and interesting.
The Intercollegiate World is truely the college man's magazine, undoubtedly the leader in its field. We sincerely hope •
that in the future it will bepme more widely known on the
campus.

WELCOME, VIRGINIA!
If present preparations are carried out, visiting teams will
receive a most cordial greeting when they arrive in Baltimore to
match their prowess with Johns Hopkins. The newly reorganized Varsity Club is to be congratulated on their admirable
!dans for meeting Virginia tomorrow. The Club has arranged
with the fraternities to have eight machines, each representing
4,ne fraternity, to meet the visiting lacrosse men, at - Union
a tion and conduct them to the field for the game. The Var,i ty Club will likewise take the men in hand at the Civil
;.:ngineering Building tea dance after the game.
•
According to indications, the Virginians will be the recipi,nt s of real Maryland hospitality. This welcoming should help
along the Indian game, which is becoming very popular at
irginia where baseball has long reigned supreme in the Spring.
. lie university that was once a great rival of Hopkins' elevens
;(is fair to become an annual opponent of the Black and Blue
ye. Welcome back again, Virginia!
C. F. R.

are available to especially qualified students.

Yale University has finally

BLUE JAY ORCHESTRA IS
WELL RECEIVED
Makes Favorable Impression Before
New York Dancers At Roseland

Having returned from a successful booking at the Roseland Dance
Hall, Broadway, the Blue Jay Orchestra is besieged with offers of
profitable bookings for the summer, according to Milton Myerberg, manager. Negotiations with
several agents are at present going
on, and the best of many offers
will be accepted.
At New York, the orchestra
played on the platform next to
Fletcher Henderson's orchestra.
This, in itself, was an honor, but
they were honored more by the
great enthusiasm with which the
critical crowds of dancers received
their music. Enoch Light, director of the orchestra, expressed-the
opinion that none of the music
they had ever played in Baltimore
could be at all comparable to the
Isyncopation produced at New
York during Easter week.. In
fact, the Blue Jays were favorably
compared to the best *and most
famous orchestras on Broadway.

NEWS-LETTER

MAILBAG
KEYES ANSWERS "TALK"
To the Editor of the et(-8-Letter:
Dear Sir:
There seems to be a good deal
of talk on the Campus regarding
the fact that we are charging only
$1.00 admission for the Army and
Oxford-Cambridge games while it
was announced at the Season
Ticket Sale that we would probably charge $1.50 or $2.00.
The decision to charge only
$1.00 was not made by any one person but was done after due consideratiOn ancl consultation with
th
various persons concerned
with such details. We were ,asked
to charge no more than $1.00 for
the English game by the person
arranging their trip and we did
not think it fair to charge $2.00
for the Army gathe only.
•
I trust that you will publish
this letter and that it will go a
long way in clearing up the minds
of the students in this matter.
We regret that- tickets may have
been sold with the idea of advance
charge on these games, but inasmuch as people holding Season
Tickets are still saving $3.60, I do
not see how. they have any cause
for complaint.
Very truly yours,
NORMAN CHASE KEYES,
Graduate Manager.

DR. THATCH RECOVERING
To the Editor of the \ cir- N-Letter:
Dear Sir:
I think a great many of your
readers wilL be interested to know
that Dr. Charles Thach, who has
been very seriously ill with sleeping sickness, is now on the way to
recovery. Dr. Thach has been in
the hospital for about eight weeks
but will be able to leave within the
next two weeks probably. He
probably will not be entirely recovered until the end of the summer but he expects to resume his
work at Washington Square College next fall.
Yours truly,
MARGARET K. THACH,
(Mrs. C. C. Thach.)

Hopkins Graduate
Wins Scholarship
Te Ming Ku, of Peking, China,
who received his A. B. degree at
Hopkins in 1921, has just won a
fellowship in Economics at Clark
University regarded as one of the
greatest honors at that institution. He has only been in America since 1922. .He is a Chinese
government student, belonging to
a prominent Peking family. Last
year he was awarded an M. A.
degree at Columbia.
